document.docAuthor: Rakotonirina, Jean Claude & Fisher, Brian L.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Pachycondyla wasmannii - group (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Malagasy region

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Pachycondyla wasmannii - group (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Malagasy region

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of the Malagasy
P. wasmannii
-group worker:

subSubSection.paragraph: The following key also identifies ergatoid and winged queens to species as long as the form of the mesosoma and the presence of the mesopleural sulcus are not applied.

caption.paragraph: FIGURES 1–2. Full-face view of the head showing the length of the antennal scape; Fig. 1: scape surpassing the posterior cephalic margin; Fig. 2: scape not surpassing the posterior cephalic margin.

FIGURES 3–4. Shape of the clypeus and location of the eyes when head in full-face view; Fig. 3: P. t a v a r a t r a , anterior clypeal margin broadly triangular; eyes breaking the lateral margin of head; Fig. 4: P. c o m ore n s i s , anterior clypeal margin truncate; eyes not breaking the lateral margin of head.

paragraph.keyLead:
3 . Basal half of the antennal scape dorsoventrally flattened, the leading edge very thin (
Fig. 5
); basitarsus of the hind leg laterally compressed, basal half of its inner surface concave...................................................
planicornis

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 5–6. Antennal scape and leading edge viewed from the back; Fig. 5: basally dorsoventrally flattened and thin in
P. planicornis
; Fig. 6: subcylindrical and rounded (e.g.,
P. cambouei
).

FIGURES 9–10. Fourth abdominal tergite in dorsal view; Fig. 9: Anterior half of the fourth abdominal tergite with dense small punctures between larger ones; Fig. 10: Anterior half of the fourth abdominal tergite smooth and shining.

FIGURES 11–12. Mesosoma in lateral view; Fig. 11: mesopleural sulcus of
P. wasmannii
complete; Fig. 12: mesopleural sulcus of P. v a zi m ba indistinct.
